_header: With this beetle be he smitten
Note:
See Gomme (1890)
XGomme, G. L. “'A Highland Folk-Tale Collected by the Late J. F. Campbell and its Origin in Custom.” Folk-Lore: A Quarterly Review of Myth, Tradition, Institution & Custom 1. (1890): 197-206, 199, 204.
Subjects: sermons, verse in; translations; illustrations, verse accompanying
_description: An English quatrain in a Latin story of the foolish father who gave away his goods, sometimes found in Bromyard’s sermons

CamTCC1450.Transcription:
With thys bytel be he smeteþat all þe worle mote hyt
                    weteþat yevyt hys goode to hys kynne& goth hym selfe a
                    beggynd
CamTCC1450.Editions:
Furnivall,  Frederick James,
                        ed.  
             Hymns to the Virgin and Christ…and other religious poems.
EETS
         o.s. 24 (1867); repr. 1973: 35.

BLRoy18Bxxiii.Transcription:
with þis betull be he smytteþat all þe world well it
                    willþat ȝeweþ þe vnkeend all is þingeand
                    goyþ hym selfe on beggynge
BLRoy18Bxxiii.Note: Written as prose. In a sermon for Septuagesima.
BLRoy18Bxxiii.Editions:
Furnivall,  Frederick James,
                        ed.  
             The Babees Book, etc.
EETS
         o.s. 32 (1868); rev. ed.  Early English Meals and

EETS

D’Evelyn,  Charlotte. 
             Peter Idley’s Instructions to His Son.
         Boston: Modern Language Association of America; and London: Oxford UP,

BLAdd35287.Transcription:
With this mace be he smeteThat al the worlde may it weteThat
                    geuyth a way his owne thyngesAnd goth hymselff a beggyng
BLAdd35287.Note:
Separate from Latin story; added to final leaf of MS by hand of the
                    fifteenth century with a crude illustration of the mace.

Eton34.Transcription:
Wyth thys betyll be he smeteAs I wyll þat all þe werld it
                    weteThat to the vnkynde ȝeue all thyngeAnd goth hymselfe on
                    beggyng
Eton34.Editions:
Lucas,  Peter J. 
             “Another Text of ‘With this beetle be he smit.’” 
             Notes and Queries
         n.s. 26 [224] (1979): 396-7: 397 (including composite text and variants).

LeicesterBRII33.Transcription:
With a Centyll be he betonthat all hys goddȝ to gyn chyldere
                    leytonAnd gyffeȝ a wey hys thyng& goys hym selff
                    abeggyng
LeicesterBRII33.Note:
With 2495 added to blank
                    folio at front.

RylandsLat394.Transcription:
With a betull be he smetonÞat alle þe world may it
                    wetenÞat ȝeues his childe alle his þyngeand gooth hym
                    selfe abegynge
RylandsLat394.Note:
Two lines, in a series of Latin & English proverbs; followed by its
                    Latin equivalent, ‘Prioli qui sua dat vt victum querere purgat /
                        Malleus hunc feriat quilibet vt videat.’
RylandsLat394.Editions:
Pantin,  William A. 
             “A Medieval Collection of Latin and English Proverbs…from Rylands
                Latin MS. 394.” 
             Bulletin of the John Rylands Library
         14 (1930): 81-114: 105.
